awd_titl_txt: AF: Large: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Proof Systems, Convexity, and Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project tackles some of the central questions in algorithms, optimization, and the theory of machine learning, through the lens of the "Sum of Squares" algorithmic framework. In particular, it will allow us to understand what classes of functions can be efficiently minimized, and what computational resources are needed to do so. If successful, this will significantly advance our understanding in all these key areas, produce new practical algorithmic methodologies, as well as build new connections with other fields, including quantum information theory, statistical physics, extremal graph theory and more.

This collaborative grant will foster new interactions between intellectual communities that have had relatively little interaction so far, and the PIs will organize workshops, courses, and other events that bring these communities together. The students and postdocs trained will gain a uniquely broad view of the landscape of these areas.

The PIs propose a unified approach to the development and analysis of convex proof systems that include and generalize the "Sum of Squares" (SoS) method. Despite considerable recent progress, understanding SoS?s performance seems to be out-of-reach for most current techniques.  Significant progress in this area requires the synthesis of ideas and techniques from different domains, including theoretical computer science, optimization, algebraic geometry, quantum information theory and machine learning. The research plans include both theory-building and problem-solving aspects, with the ultimate goal of obtaining a complete understanding of the SoS method and related proof systems, as well as their algorithmic implications.

Research efforts will be directed along several thrusts: Unique Games and related problems (Small Set Expansion, Max Cut, Sparsest Cut), analysis of average-case problems (e.g., Planted Clique), applications to Machine Learning (sparse PCA, dictionary learning), algorithmic speedups of SoS, and connections to math and physics (e.g., quantum entanglement, p-spin glasses, extremal graph theory and algebraic geometry). While the main focus is on theoretical aspects, this project is also concerned with effective computational methods, and the outcomes may yield novel practical techniques for machine learning and optimization.

Other key features of this proposal include its strong integration with curriculum development, undergraduate research projects, and training the next wave of graduate students and postdocs and equipping them with the necessary tools to work across these areas.

por.por_cntn:
The sum-of-squares hierarchy is a powerful family of semidefinite programming relaxations. It is increasingly playing a central role in theoretical computer science, where it leads to state-of-the-art algorithms and gives strong forms of evidence of intractability. The goal of this project is to further develop our understanding of the sum-of-squares algorithm along several complementary dimensions, including (1) establishing a unified framework for reasoning about its performance, particularly for average-case problems (2) broadening its reach by using it to design new algorithms for fundamental problems in adjacent fields (3) developing new techniques for speeding up the sum-of-squares algorithm, and applying it to machine learning problems and (4) exploring connections to quantum information theory and combinatorics. 

Planted Clique and Pseudocalibration: A major goal of this project was to resolve the question: Does the sum-of-squares algorithm refute the planted clique hypothesis? In the planted clique problem, the goal is to recover a clique that has been added to an Erdos-Renyi random graph. There are wide gaps between the performance of the best known algorithms when compared to the information theoretic limits of what is possible with brute force search. In recent years, much of our understanding of computational vs. statistical tradeoffs has been built on the assumption that finding a planted clique is hard. The PIs and collaborators showed an almost optimal lower bound for the planted clique problem. This involved developing a new technique, called pseudocalibration, that gives a general recipe for constructing candidate integrality gaps for average-case problems that evade some of the sophisticated forms of Bayesian reasoning that can be performed by the sum-of-squares hierarchy. This technique has led to rapid progress on many other average-case problems. 

Applications in Control: The celebrated Kalman filter gives a statistically optimal algorithm for estimating the trajectory of a linear dynamical system. However when the process or observation noise are non-gaussian, it can breakdown badly. Building on recent progress in algorithmic statistics (particularly ways of designing robust estimators through the sum-of-squares hierarchy), PI Moitra and collaborators developed a robust alternative to the Kalman filter. Their estimator is based on a suite of new techniques to combine the sum-of-squares hierarchy complex constraints on the trajectory across different time steps and scales.

Speeding up Sum-of-Squares: Another central goal of this project is to show how the sum-of-squares method, or insights derived from it, can be made practical. Towards that end, motivated by applications in statistical inference and quantum information, PI Parrilo and collaborators developed a new framework for approximating the exponential and relative entropy cones. Their approach was based on integral representations and Pade approximations, which nicely extend to the matrix setting. These methods turn out to be significantly faster than existing approaches in large-scale optimization settings. In a separate line of work, PI Parrilo and collaborators explored the use of gradient-based local methods as an alternative to computationally expensive SDPs. PI Moitra and collaborators studied the tensor completion problem where the goal is to estimate an incoherent low rank tensor from random observations. Earlier work of PIs Barak and Moitra gave an algorithm based on the sum-of-squares hierarchy. PI Moitra and collaborators leveraged their analysis to design new spectral algorithms that run in nearly-linear time. Their method turns out to be slight twist on an existing heuristic called alternating minimization, and they show that their variant not only has provable guarantees but scales to tensors with thousands of dimensions.

Directed Laplacians: The Laplacian paradigm has led to a revolution in graph algorithms, whereby classic problems like computing a maximum flow or sampling a random spanning tree, can be done faster by utilizing solving Laplacian linear systems as a subroutine. However many other fundamental graph problems, particularly those involving Markov chains, have remained out of reach. PI Kelner and collaborators gave a nearly linear time algorithm for solving Laplacian linear systems of directed graphs, and gave a number of striking implications of this result, including the first nearly linear time algorithms for computing the stationary distribution, personalized PageRank vectors, hitting times, and escape probabilities. This raises the hope that semidefinite programming techniques that thus far had been based on exploiting structure in undirected graphs might have direct analogues in the directed case as well. 

Identifiability via Generating Functions: Previously, there were provable algorithms for learning gaussian mixture models and (separately) for learning a single gaussian in the face of adversarial corruptions. One of the central open questions in algorithmic robust statistics was to combine the two, and give a provably robust algorithm for learning gaussian mixture models. PI Moitra and collaborators developed an novel and powerful approach to this question, based on generating functions and differential operators. Furthermore they showed that these arguments could be carried out in the sum-of-squares proof system, thus giving the first robust algorithms for learning gaussian mixture models as a byproduct.
